attachments.text: A way to achieve this is using the pgfplots backend to save the figure into a tikzpicture. Instead of adjusting the size before you produce the plot, you can adjust the size in the generated .tex file. By using the package pgfplots in LaTeX, the plot will be drawn directly in the PDF, where you can adjust the size, fonts, colors, and any other property you can think of. text: I disagree :slightly_smiling_face: I was pointing to Makie.jl as _my_ favorite Julia package for making publication-quality PDFs. In a sense, Plots.jl is a package just like Makie.jl is another one, so maybe there is some confusion that Plots.jl is a standard library of Julia or something like that? From my point of view, having tried a bunch of the plotting tools available in Julia, I see very few shortcomings in plotting. You can use Plots and all its backends, or the backend packages directly (GR.jl, PyPlot.jl, PGFPlotX.jl, VegaLite.jl, and so on), or entirely separate packages like Makie.jl.

I got that mwe working, a trip through latex stackoverflow, there were some missing tex packages. For the xticks, I have this line
```DOFs = 1e3 .* 2 .^ collect(1:2:10)
xticks!(DOFs .^ (-1/2), "\$" .* string.(DOFs) .* "^{-\\frac{1}{2}}\$")```
So I pick a range of DOFs, then do the transform to get the relevant `h` values to plot the labels at (this is for a 2D example)

text:
Otherwise, FWIW, I came up with this to get you started in Makie if you want:
```DOFP1 = [32000, 8000, 2000, 500]
xP1 = repeat(DOFP1 .^ (-1/3), inner=10)
yP1 = @. xP1 + 0.01randn()

using CairoMakie

fig = Figure(resolution=(600,600))

ax = fig[1,1] = Axis(fig)

scatter!(ax, log10.(xP1), log10.(yP1), marker=:xcross, markersize=20, color=RGBAf0(1.0, 0.0, 0.0, 0.5), strokewidth=0)

ax.xticks = sort(unique(log10.(xP1)))
ax.xtickformat = xs -> ["$(Int(round(exp10(x)^-3)))⁻¹ᐟ³" for x in xs]

save(joinpath(homedir(), "tmp/MWE_MATLAB_to_Makie.pdf"), fig)```
